trans-unit.source: List Azure Storage Resources with the Microsoft Azure Storage Client Library for C++ | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: List Azure Storage Resources with the Microsoft Azure Storage Client Library for C++ | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the listing APIs in Microsoft Azure Storage Client Library for C++ to enumerate containers, blobs, queues, tables, and entities.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the listing APIs in Microsoft Azure Storage Client Library for C++ to enumerate containers, blobs, queues, tables, and entities.

trans-unit.source: List Azure Storage Resources in C++
trans-unit.target: List Azure Storage Resources in C++

trans-unit.source: Listing operations are key to many development scenarios with Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Listing operations are key to many development scenarios with Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to most efficiently enumerate objects in Azure Storage using the listing APIs provided in the Microsoft Azure Storage Client Library for C++.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to most efficiently enumerate objects in Azure Storage using the listing APIs provided in the Microsoft Azure Storage Client Library for C++.

trans-unit.source: This guide targets the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ version 1.x, which is available via <link><linkText>NuGet</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This guide targets the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ version 1.x, which is available via <link><linkText>NuGet</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Client Library provides a variety of methods to list or query objects in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: The Storage Client Library provides a variety of methods to list or query objects in Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: This article addresses the following scenarios:
trans-unit.target: This article addresses the following scenarios:

trans-unit.source: List containers in an account
trans-unit.target: List containers in an account

trans-unit.source: List blobs in a container or virtual blob directory
trans-unit.target: List blobs in a container or virtual blob directory

trans-unit.source: List queues in an account
trans-unit.target: List queues in an account

trans-unit.source: List tables in an account
trans-unit.target: List tables in an account

trans-unit.source: Query entities in a table
trans-unit.target: Query entities in a table

trans-unit.source: Each of these methods is shown using different overloads for different scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Each of these methods is shown using different overloads for different scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Asynchronous versus synchronous
trans-unit.target: Asynchronous versus synchronous

trans-unit.source: Because the Storage Client Library for C++ is built on top of the <link><linkText>C++ REST library (Project Casablanca)</linkText><title></title></link>, we inherently support asynchronous operations by using <link><linkText>pplx::task</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Because the Storage Client Library for C++ is built on top of the <link><linkText>C++ REST library (Project Casablanca)</linkText><title></title></link>, we inherently support asynchronous operations by using <link><linkText>pplx::task</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Synchronous operations wrap the corresponding asynchronous operations:
trans-unit.target: Synchronous operations wrap the corresponding asynchronous operations:

trans-unit.source: If you are working with multiple threading applications or services, we recommend that you use the async APIs directly instead of creating a thread to call the sync APIs, which significantly impacts your performance.
trans-unit.target: If you are working with multiple threading applications or services, we recommend that you use the async APIs directly instead of creating a thread to call the sync APIs, which significantly impacts your performance.

trans-unit.source: Segmented listing
trans-unit.target: Segmented listing

trans-unit.source: The scale of cloud storage requires segmented listing.
trans-unit.target: The scale of cloud storage requires segmented listing.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can have over a million blobs in an Azure blob container or over a billion entities in an Azure Table.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can have over a million blobs in an Azure blob container or over a billion entities in an Azure Table.

trans-unit.source: These are not theoretical numbers, but real customer usage cases.
trans-unit.target: These are not theoretical numbers, but real customer usage cases.

trans-unit.source: It is therefore impractical to list all objects in a single response.
trans-unit.target: It is therefore impractical to list all objects in a single response.

trans-unit.source: Instead, you can list objects using paging.
trans-unit.target: Instead, you can list objects using paging.

trans-unit.source: Each of the listing APIs has a segmented overload.
trans-unit.target: Each of the listing APIs has a segmented overload.

trans-unit.source: The response for a segmented listing operation includes:
trans-unit.target: The response for a segmented listing operation includes:

trans-unit.source: <html></html>_segment<html></html>, which contains the set of results returned for a single call to the listing API.
trans-unit.target: <html></html>_segment<html></html>, which contains the set of results returned for a single call to the listing API.

trans-unit.source: continuation_token, which is passed to the next call in order to get the next page of results.
trans-unit.target: continuation_token, which is passed to the next call in order to get the next page of results.

trans-unit.source: When there are no more results to return, the continuation token is null.
trans-unit.target: When there are no more results to return, the continuation token is null.

trans-unit.source: For example, a typical call to list all blobs in a container may look like the following code snippet.
trans-unit.target: For example, a typical call to list all blobs in a container may look like the following code snippet.

trans-unit.source: The code is available in our <link><linkText>samples</linkText><title></title></link>:
trans-unit.target: The code is available in our <link><linkText>samples</linkText><title></title></link>:

trans-unit.source: Note that the number of results returned in a page can be controlled by the parameter max_results in the overload of each API, for example:
trans-unit.target: Note that the number of results returned in a page can be controlled by the parameter max_results in the overload of each API, for example:

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify the max_results parameter, the default maximum value of up to 5000 results is returned in a single page.
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify the max_results parameter, the default maximum value of up to 5000 results is returned in a single page.

trans-unit.source: Also note that a query against Azure Table storage may return no records, or fewer records than the value of the max_results parameter that you specified, even if the continuation token is not empty.
trans-unit.target: Also note that a query against Azure Table storage may return no records, or fewer records than the value of the max_results parameter that you specified, even if the continuation token is not empty.

trans-unit.source: One reason might be that the query could not complete in five seconds.
trans-unit.target: One reason might be that the query could not complete in five seconds.

trans-unit.source: As long as the continuation token is not empty, the query should continue, and your code should not assume the size of segment results.
trans-unit.target: As long as the continuation token is not empty, the query should continue, and your code should not assume the size of segment results.

trans-unit.source: The recommended coding pattern for most scenarios is segmented listing, which provides explicit progress of listing or querying, and how the service responds to each request.
trans-unit.target: The recommended coding pattern for most scenarios is segmented listing, which provides explicit progress of listing or querying, and how the service responds to each request.

trans-unit.source: Particularly for C++ applications or services, lower-level control of the listing progress may help control memory and performance.
trans-unit.target: Particularly for C++ applications or services, lower-level control of the listing progress may help control memory and performance.

trans-unit.source: Greedy listing
trans-unit.target: Greedy listing

trans-unit.source: Earlier versions of the Storage Client Library for C++ (versions 0.5.0 Preview and earlier) included non-segmented listing APIs for tables and queues, as in the following example:
trans-unit.target: Earlier versions of the Storage Client Library for C++ (versions 0.5.0 Preview and earlier) included non-segmented listing APIs for tables and queues, as in the following example:

trans-unit.source: These methods were implemented as wrappers of segmented APIs.
trans-unit.target: These methods were implemented as wrappers of segmented APIs.

trans-unit.source: For each response of segmented listing, the code appended the results to a vector and returned all results after the full containers were scanned.
trans-unit.target: For each response of segmented listing, the code appended the results to a vector and returned all results after the full containers were scanned.

trans-unit.source: This approach might work when the storage account or table contains a small number of objects.
trans-unit.target: This approach might work when the storage account or table contains a small number of objects.

trans-unit.source: However, with an increase in the number of objects, the memory required could increase without limit, because all results remained in memory.
trans-unit.target: However, with an increase in the number of objects, the memory required could increase without limit, because all results remained in memory.

trans-unit.source: One listing operation can take a very long time, during which the caller had no information about its progress.
trans-unit.target: One listing operation can take a very long time, during which the caller had no information about its progress.

trans-unit.source: These greedy listing APIs in the SDK do not exist in C#, Java, or the JavaScript Node.js environment.
trans-unit.target: These greedy listing APIs in the SDK do not exist in C#, Java, or the JavaScript Node.js environment.

trans-unit.source: To avoid the potential issues of using these greedy APIs, we removed them in version 0.6.0 Preview.
trans-unit.target: To avoid the potential issues of using these greedy APIs, we removed them in version 0.6.0 Preview.

trans-unit.source: If your code is calling these greedy APIs:
trans-unit.target: If your code is calling these greedy APIs:

trans-unit.source: Then you should modify your code to use the segmented listing APIs:
trans-unit.target: Then you should modify your code to use the segmented listing APIs:

trans-unit.source: By specifying the max_results parameter of the segment, you can balance between the numbers of requests and memory usage to meet performance considerations for your application.
trans-unit.target: By specifying the max_results parameter of the segment, you can balance between the numbers of requests and memory usage to meet performance considerations for your application.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, if you’re using segmented listing APIs, but store the data in a local collection in a "greedy" style, we also strongly recommend that you refactor your code to handle storing data in a local collection carefully at scale.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, if you’re using segmented listing APIs, but store the data in a local collection in a "greedy" style, we also strongly recommend that you refactor your code to handle storing data in a local collection carefully at scale.

trans-unit.source: Lazy listing
trans-unit.target: Lazy listing

trans-unit.source: Although greedy listing raised potential issues, it is convenient if there are not too many objects in the container.
trans-unit.target: Although greedy listing raised potential issues, it is convenient if there are not too many objects in the container.

trans-unit.source: If you’re also using C# or Oracle Java SDKs, you should be familiar with the Enumerable programming model, which offers a lazy-style listing, where the data at a certain offset is only fetched if it is required.
trans-unit.target: If you’re also using C# or Oracle Java SDKs, you should be familiar with the Enumerable programming model, which offers a lazy-style listing, where the data at a certain offset is only fetched if it is required.

trans-unit.source: In C++, the iterator-based template also provides a similar approach.
trans-unit.target: In C++, the iterator-based template also provides a similar approach.

trans-unit.source: A typical lazy listing API, using list_blobs as an example, looks like this:
trans-unit.target: A typical lazy listing API, using list_blobs as an example, looks like this:

trans-unit.source: A typical code snippet that uses the lazy listing pattern might look like this:
trans-unit.target: A typical code snippet that uses the lazy listing pattern might look like this:

trans-unit.source: Note that lazy listing is only available in synchronous mode.
trans-unit.target: Note that lazy listing is only available in synchronous mode.

trans-unit.source: Compared with greedy listing, lazy listing fetches data only when necessary.
trans-unit.target: Compared with greedy listing, lazy listing fetches data only when necessary.

trans-unit.source: Under the covers, it fetches data from Azure Storage only when the next iterator moves into next segment.
trans-unit.target: Under the covers, it fetches data from Azure Storage only when the next iterator moves into next segment.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, memory usage is controlled with a bounded size, and the operation is fast.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, memory usage is controlled with a bounded size, and the operation is fast.

trans-unit.source: Lazy listing APIs are included in the Storage Client Library for C++ in version 1.0.0.
trans-unit.target: Lazy listing APIs are included in the Storage Client Library for C++ in version 1.0.0.

trans-unit.source: Conclusion
trans-unit.target: Conclusion

trans-unit.source: In this article, we discussed different overloads for listing APIs for various objects in the Storage Client Library for C++ .
trans-unit.target: In this article, we discussed different overloads for listing APIs for various objects in the Storage Client Library for C++ .

trans-unit.source: To summarize:
trans-unit.target: To summarize:

trans-unit.source: Async APIs are strongly recommended under multiple threading scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Async APIs are strongly recommended under multiple threading scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Segmented listing is recommended for most scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Segmented listing is recommended for most scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Lazy listing is provided in the library as a convenient wrapper in synchronous scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Lazy listing is provided in the library as a convenient wrapper in synchronous scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Greedy listing is not recommended and has been removed from the library.
trans-unit.target: Greedy listing is not recommended and has been removed from the library.
